abstract.text: Tells the file provider to return an enumerator for the provided directory.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The item identifier for the directory.
An object that identifies the context of that request, such as the requesting app.
An enumerator for the specified directory.
The system calls this method to request an enumerator for the specified item.
Possible item identifiers include:
The system passes this identifier when the user begins browsing your file provider’s content.
The system requests a new enumerator each time the user opens a new directory.
A directory’s
The system can request an enumerator so that it can sync the working set in the background.
The system subscribes to live updates by requesting an enumerator for a document.
A document’s

The system passes this identifier when the user browses the contents of the trash. If your File Provider extension doesn’t support moving items to the trash, your implementation should throw or return an error.
The
directory.
Your implementation should create and return an
object that provides the requested content.
If you can’t return the requested enumerator, you must throw an error in Swift, or if you return nil in Objective-C, you must set the
out parameter.
If the
parameter is
and your extension doesn’t support trashing items, then it should fail with the
error code from the
domain. Additionally, make sure the items managed by your File Provider extension don’t have the
capability enabled.
If the
parameter doesn’t exist in your remote storage, you should fail with an
error. The system then attempts to delete the item from disk.
If you pass
or
to the handler, the system presents an appropriate alert to the user, but doesn’t try to access the metadata until triggered again by the user.
The system considers any other errors to be transient, and automatically retries the method call.

abstract.text: The feature isn’t supported, because the file system lacks the feature, or required libraries are missing, or other similar reasons.
An extension other apps use to access files and folders managed by your app and synced with a remote storage.
Support for enumerating the file provider’s contents.
Tells the file provider to return an enumerator for the provided directory.
A protocol for enumerating items and changes.
An error indicating that the specified item doesn’t exist.
An error indicating that you can’t verify the user’s credentials.
An error indicating that the File Provider extension can’t reach the remote server.
A value indicating that the item can be moved to the trash.
A unique identifier for an item managed by the File Provider extension.
The persistent identifier for the root directory of the file provider’s shared file hierarchy.
The persistent identifier for the parent of all trashed items.
The persistent identifier representing the working set of documents and directories.
An object that provides information about the application requesting data from the File Provider extension.
Keep the local and remote copies of your File Provider extension’s content in sync.
Information about an error condition including a domain, a domain-specific error code, and application-specific information.

inlineContent.text: The item identifier for the directory.
An object that identifies the context of that request, such as the requesting app.
On output, a pointer to an error object that describes why the method failed, or
if no error occurred. If you are not interested in the error information, pass
for this parameter.
An enumerator for the specified directory.
